content: The Act may be cited as the "Helping Ensure Long-Term Protection for Coal Miners Health Care Act of 2017" or the "HELP for Coal Miners Health Care Act of 2017". Congress acknowledges the struggles faced by the coal industry and its communities due to overregulation, leading to job losses, mine closures, and bankruptcies since President Obama's inauguration. Since President Obama's inauguration, Kentucky has lost over 10,000 coal mining jobs, and the total number of operating coal mines has reached a record low. Due to health risks in mining, many coal companies are unable to provide health benefits to retirees and their dependents. Congress has intervened in 1992, 2006, and in 2016 to secure health benefits for retired miners, providing a 4-month extension in the last instance. It is crucial to provide a permanent extension of health care benefits for retired miners and their dependents to prevent the loss of retirement health benefits. SEC. 3. INCLUSION OF CERTAIN RETIREES IN THE MULTIEMPLOYER HEALTH BENEFIT PLAN. The Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 is amended to calculate excess for beneficiaries enrolled in the Plan under the HELP for Coal Miners Health Care Act of 2017. The Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 is amended to calculate excess for beneficiaries enrolled in the Plan under the HELP for Coal Miners Health Care Act of 2017, excluding certain beneficiaries on the first day of the calendar year for which the transfer is made. The coal wage agreement would be denied or reduced due to a bankruptcy proceeding in 2012 or 2015. Beneficiaries enrolled in the Plan as of the enactment of the HELP for Coal Miners Health Care Act of 2017 are deemed eligible for health benefits on January 1, 2017. Certain retirees are treated as eligible to receive health benefits. The amendments made by this section apply to fiscal years beginning after September 30, 2016. The amount of transfer for a fiscal year shall be reduced by any amount transferred to the Plan to pay benefits required under the Plan from a voluntary employees' beneficiary association established as a result of a bankruptcy proceeding. Every 3 years, the Comptroller General of the United States will study the Multiemployer Health Benefit Plan under the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 to analyze the appropriate use of Federal funds by the Plan. SEC. 4. CLARIFICATION OF FINANCING OBLIGATIONS. In section 9704 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, amendments are made to reduce the number of premiums and accounts required. Subsection (a) is amended to change the number of premiums from three to two. Subsection (b) includes conforming amendments, such as redesignating subsections and reducing the number of separate accounts required. Amendments are made to reduce the number of premiums and accounts required in section 9704 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes changing the number of premiums from three to two and making conforming amendments to subsections. Amendments are made to reduce the number of premiums and accounts required in section 9704 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes changing the number of premiums from three to two and making conforming amendments to subsections by striking certain references and inserting new ones. Additionally, the elimination of an additional backstop premium is addressed by removing a specific subparagraph in section 9712(d) of the Code. The amendments made by this section involve reducing the number of premiums and accounts required in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes changing the number of premiums from three to two and making adjustments for annual adjustments. The effective date for these amendments is plan years beginning after September 30, 2016. SENSE OF THE SENATE: Congress should work with the administration to repeal regulations harming the coal industry and support economic growth in coal communities.
